title: How to Choose a Ramp or Stairs for Your Cat

steps.title: Purchase stairs when your cat begins to avoid high places.
steps.content: Purchase stairs when your cat begins to avoid high places. Stairs are a great option for cats who find it uncomfortable to jump high but otherwise get around well. Cats like to hide illness, so you will need to watch attentively. If your cat suddenly starts to avoid high perches that it had once loved, then it might be time for stairs. [1] X Research source Your cat might have a problem if it has begun to avoid its cat tree. Also consider stairs if it has begun to sleep on the ground. Most cats prefer to sleep in a high perch.

steps.title: Purchase stairs to conserve space.
steps.content: Purchase stairs to conserve space. Stairs take up less space than ramps. You can even buy stairs that are collapsible or easily transportable, so that you can put them away or move them if necessary. They have a steeper incline and thus are not as long. If your cat can manage stairs, it might be the more convenient option than a ramp. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Look for steps no taller than 7 ½”.
steps.content: Look for steps no taller than 7 ½”. Each individual step should be no more than 7 ½” or 19 cm tall. This should be a comfortable height for your cat to climb. A steeper incline could make it hard for your cat to use the stairs. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Look for stairs at least 10” deep.
steps.content: Look for stairs at least 10” deep. Your cat likes to have space to maneuver on the step. Be sure that the steps are each at least 10” (25 cm) deep. Dogs are less interested in this space, so stairs designed for them might not have the depth required for cat stairs. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Purchase a ramp if your cat has trouble walking.
steps.content: Purchase a ramp if your cat has trouble walking. Stairs are great for cats who can’t jump high but can otherwise get around well. When you suspect that your cat is beginning to have trouble even walking around, then it is time to move on to a ramp. It usually helps to get cats accustomed to ramps ahead of time, so consider buying them when your cat first experiences mobility problems. [5] X Research source Cats like to hide their ailments, so it might be hard to tell when it begins to have mobility issues. By 15, you cat is likely to have some discomfort walking. Watch for changes in its gait. Look for signs that it is walking less or using less stairs less frequently.

steps.title: Purchase a ramp if your cat has never used stairs.
steps.content: Purchase a ramp if your cat has never used stairs. Some cats never take to stairs and will be especially unlikely to use stairs if you introduce them to your cat late in life. If you cat has traditionally avoided stairs or has never had a chance to use them before, a ramp might be a safer bet. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Get a gentler slope for struggling cats.
steps.content: Get a gentler slope for struggling cats. A slope of 18 degrees might be necessary for cats with a very severe impairment. For those with only moderate difficulties, something as steep as 26 degrees might be appropriate. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Choose a model with non-looping carpet.
steps.content: Choose a model with non-looping carpet. Carpet is optimal because it provides traction and prevents your cat from slipping off. However, your cat’s nails can get stuck in carpet that has small loops. Try a non-looping carpet like plush. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Buy a model with safety rails.
steps.content: Buy a model with safety rails. There should be rails along the side of the stairs that will stop your cat if it begins to fall off. This is especially important if your cat is losing its sight; it might be the only way that it knows where it is going. [9] X Research source If your cat loses its vision slowly, it will probably be hard for you to recognize the problem. Your cat will memorize the location of items in the household and act as if nothing has changed. However, it will bump into furniture more often than it used to, especially when you move furniture around. It might also seem more reticent to jump from high spots. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Be sure that the model is tall enough.
steps.content: Be sure that the model is tall enough. The top step of stairs should be no less than 7 1/2” (25 cm) shorter than the surface it leads up to. A ramp should be high enough to be level with the surface.

steps.title: Choose a low-lying ramp or stair for cats with mobility problems.
steps.content: Choose a low-lying ramp or stair for cats with mobility problems. If your cat is older or if it has difficulty moving, try to keep the cat low to the ground in case it falls. Get a ramp for a couch, bed, or chair, but do not get ramps for windows, high perches, closet shelves, or bookcases.

steps.title: Place treats on the ramp to encourage your cat to use it.
steps.content: Place treats on the ramp to encourage your cat to use it. Your cat may not start using the ramp right away. To help it get used to the ramp, put a treat in middle of the ramp or stair. Once it is on it, put another treat on the top of the ramp. This will teach your cat how to get up using the ramp or stair. Give your cat plenty of time to get used to the ramp. Even with treats, your cat may not want to use it right away.
